repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project under the Global
            Program for Avian Influenza (GPAI)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Avian Influenza Control
            and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project under
            the Global Program for Avian Influenza (GPAI) for Romania
            were as follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was significant, monitoring and
            evaluation was negligible, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: countries
            that have already effectively controlled avian influenza
            outbreaks in poultry many not need an emergency project, but
            rather long term capacity building. The real emergency issue
            was European Union (EU) accession, but after accession was
            achieved the government lost interest in the project. The
            evaluation also notes that following this project, avian
            influenza is still a threat to Romania. Avian influenza
            risks cannot be minimized without ensuring adequate capacity
            in the animal health sector and adequate biosecurity in the
            poultry sector. Project designs that do not improve
            biosecurity on commercial farms or backyard systems will
            miss an opportunity to reduce the likelihood of avian
            influenza outbreaks.

Romania - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project under the Global
            Program for Avian Influenza (GPAI)

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Avian Influenza Control
            and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project for
            Romania were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: it is important for the Bank
            to be proactive and use its various tools (such as
            suspension of disbursements, re-allocation to faster
            disbursing sub-components, cancellation, and restructuring)
            to give a project a chance to go forward more efficiently
            and smoothly. For example, restructuring of the project
            enabled it to achieve many positive results. Even though a
            project such as an avian influenza project needs to be
            prepared in a hurry and within a short period of time to
            respond to an emergency situation, it is essential to see
            that basics aspects for successful implementation are in
            place. Purchasing equipment for health projects, especially
            for an input-based project such as an avian influenza
            project, is generally complicated and time consuming, and a
            lot of efforts will be required to manage these types of
            projects. For these reasons, sufficient time should be
            allowed for completing the project activities, with
            considerations for possible delays in procurement.

Romania - Plan de adquisiciones y
            contrataciones : procurement plan

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Avian Influenza
            Control and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project
            for Romania is to assist the Borrower in building its
            capacity to respond to potential future infections of humans
            by Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) and other
            zoonoses, and preparing for, controlling and responding to
            influenza pandemics and other infectious disease emergencies
            in humans. The changes will be undertaken pursuant to a
            request by the Borrower, received on March 31, 2009, for
            reallocation and partial cancellation of the loan. Pursuant
            to this request, the Bank cancelled EUR 7,317,233 of the
            loan on April 3, 2009, leaving EUR 3.9 million available
            from the National Sanitary, Veterinary, and Food Safety
            Authority (ANSVSA), managed activities for reallocation to
            the human health component as requested by the Borrower. The
            cancellation has made project restructuring necessary on the
            occasion of which the requested reallocation can be
            undertaken. The request by the Borrower was made against the
            following background: (a) the institution responsible for
            the implementation of the animal health component has proven
            unable to effectively manage the implementation of the
            project in accordance with the provisions of the loan
            agreement and the project implementation manual, resulting
            in significant implementation delays that made the
            achievement of the Project Development Objective (PDO)
            unlikely. ANSVSA-managed parts of the project have been
            under suspension since November 13, 2008, and the requested
            corrective action required for the Bank to consider the
            lifting of the suspension was not taken by the set deadline
            of March 31, 2009; and (b) the Ministry of Public Health
            (MPH) - responsible for the implementation of part two of
            the project, has requested additional resources to cover a
            cost overrun in actual bids and to cover expenditures for
            additional items, not foreseen at appraisal, which are
            needed to complete the agreed activities under that component.

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Avian Influenza and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for
            Romania Avian Influenza and human pandemic preparedness and
            response project will have minor building works required for
            construction or rehabilitation of the existing structures
            will not imply the use of any valuable resources. The
            fertile soil removed should be stored in a special place in
            order to be used later. Main adverse effects are those
            characteristic to any construction activity that implies
            digging works and eventually the use of heavy equipment and
            transport vehicles: dust from digging process; exhausted gas
            emission and noise and vibrations from construction
            equipment and vehicles; disturbance of small wild fauna and
            vegetation; soil pollution caused by oil and grease leakage
            and improper solid waste disposal. Due to the small area
            used as well as to the short time period necessary for
            construction, the environmental impact is low and temporary.
            The construction company has full responsibility to take all
            necessary mitigation measures: strict delimitation of
            construction area by fence and/or warning belts;
            sound-absorbent panels around the construction area; use of
            dust-absorbing screens; compliance with construction work
            regulations; setting up of waste management system;
            maintenance of vehicles and construction equipment in
            special places only. Costs for these measures should be
            supported by the local administration.

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Avian Influenza Control and Human
            Pandemic Preparedness and Response (APL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Romania Avian Influenza Control and
            Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response (APL) Project
            supports and constitutes an integral part of a national
            program to increase Romania's avian and human influenza
            preparedness. In this context, the overall development
            objective o f the project is to reduce the threat posed to
            humans and the poultry sector in Romania by Avian Flu and
            other zoonoses, and to support the preparation for, control
            of, and response to influenza pandemics and other infectious
            disease emergencies in humans. The project has three
            components each with multiple sub-components that support
            activities in prevention, preparedness, contingency
            planning, response, and containment. Component 1 focuses on
            animal health: it strengthens veterinary institutions;
            improves Avian Flu prevention and control planning;
            strengthens monitoring and surveillance systems, diagnostic
            capacity, animal diseases information systems, applied
            veterinary research capacity, and Avian flu control
            programs; supports poultry vaccination campaigns; and
            improves bio-security in poultry production and trade.
            Component 2 focuses on human health by enhancing Public
            Health Program Planning and Coordination; and Strengthening
            o f National Public Health Surveillance Systems and the
            health system's response capacity. Component 3 funds
            public awareness, communication, and implementation support.
